reviewText: You should buy this game and play it right now, if you like great adventure stories with great characters, intense chase scenes, unexpected reveals, epic battles and hilarious humor: from regular jokes to comical action and situations. Sometimes it's silly, sometimes it's serious, but it's always handled perfectly. One thing, though. Don't expect a lot of freedom with the gameplay, because this game is basically a cutscenefest (gorgeously directed, btw), where all you do is choose dialog/action options. It's completely fine, though. It's meant to be this way. Sometimes you can walk around a room or two, and talk to people to hear additional dialogs or interact with stuff (not even puzzle type) to advance the story. That being said, I love every episode of this game.\n\n11/10

reviewText:
You would need to have a tremendous dislike for Borderlands as a franchise to avoid stating Tales from the Borderlands might easily be the best game Telltale ever made.  And I'm saying that as someone who's not really much of a Borderlands fan AND who has consistently had a bone to pick with Telltale's approach to game design.

Game follows standard Telltale interactive adventure formula with a twist of having two main characters to control this time around, even if they are both on the snarky side to begin with, and benefits from the addition of largely tangential elements like Fiona's wallet or Ryhs' cybernetic eye which really only come up in rare few situations where they were actually used in some meaningful way. They were still good additions though, and precisely what these games need to involve you further on some mechanical level even if it is just inteacting with couple of windows and additional button presses. It should be noted this is by far the most light-hearted game as befitting its native franchise and this comes through in general  atmosphere, characters themselves and writting overall resulting in incredibly zany situations and even crazier directions story goes towards. I would also say a much-complained-about-wait for the final episode was well worth it having finally played it considering it pulls off some decent story resolutions as well as new last-minute system additions I did not see coming while still keeping the doors open for a potential season two.

In the end, Telltale really outdid themselves with this one and is probably their new benchmark as of right now.

reviewText: Unlike The Walking Dead where the only thing you can expect is sadness and your favorite characters dying, Tales from the Borderlands has everything that a good story needs. It does have that sadness, but it also has comedy to that will always make you chuckle or laugh out loud, fantastic and memorable characters, heartwarming moments, fun QTEs (YES, FUN QTES), and dark moments that remind you that you're playing a Borderlands game. Your choices do matter and it'll be shown as the series progresses, especially in the climax. Tales from the Borderlands has quickly replaced The Walking Dead for my favorite Telltale game for the reasons I just mentioned. So treat yourself, buy this game!

reviewText: You should buy this game and play it right now, if you like great adventure stories with great characters, intense chase scenes, unexpected reveals, epic battles and hilarious humor: from regular jokes to comical action and situations. Sometimes it's silly, sometimes it's serious, but it's always handled perfectly. One thing, though. Don't expect a lot of freedom with the gameplay, because this game is basically a cutscenefest (gorgeously directed, btw), where all you do is choose dialog/action options. It's completely fine, though. It's meant to be this way. Sometimes you can walk around a room or two, and talk to people to hear additional dialogs or interact with stuff (not even puzzle type) to advance the story. That being said, I love every episode of this game.\n\n11/10

reviewText: The Wolf Among Us has long held the title of my favourite 'choice based game', staying well ahead of the competition posed by Life is Strange or Telltale's Walking Dead.  This game has taken that title by miles.   Tales from the Borderlands is both one of the most heartfelt and the funniest story to come out of Telltale, and manages to maintain the style of the main Borderlands games while having a far better story and much more realistic dialogue.  The characters in this game are far more relatable than any of the previous protagonists, and you will probably care far more about them because of it, especially in the moments when Telltale pulls their signature 'everything went wrong' moments out.  But through all the drama it maintains a generally lighthearted tone, with lots of laughs from both physical humour and great writing.  It also has the two best action scenes in any game of this genre.  I won't go into details for fear of ruining the surprises, but believe me that you'll know them when you see them.\n\nThis is a must play whether you care about the main series of Borderlands or not.  If you've never played the originals, they're good games in their own right, but a wiki summary of the series will be enough for you to get a great experience out of this one.  A full recommendation from me.  CATCH A RIIIIIIIIDE!

reviewText:
This game is wonderful! I actually hate the Borderlands games but now I don't hate the universe. If you liked Wolf Among Us or Walking Dead you will enjoy this. There's a lot of tongue-in-cheek dialogue so if that bothers you then steer clear of this one.

I loved everything about it except the currency system.

Also (unsurprisingly) Troy Baker is in it as well as Nolan North so....there's that.

Finally I'm dissapointed in some of the narrow-minded comments about it not being a game. Video Games (IMO) are interactive stories, the reason I love them is because they allow me to be a participator rather than just an observer. This game also allows that. So by definition this is a real video game whether you agree or not and it's a doosey!

reviewText: No this is not the normal FPS borderlands thing I'm sure you're used to. When you think borderlands one of the things that comes to mind is like a bajillion guns, interesting characters, skags, vaults, and the best and worst Pandora has to offer. We get space, Hyperion buttheads, and that sweet smell of pyscos getting a little stabby. I really enjoyed it.  It may not be the FPS you're used to when playing borderlands but it's got that borderlands feel. The characters very interesting. I enjoyed The walking dead and Wolf Amoug Us by Telltale and they did a good job on this game. The character switches was a nice touch. Rys and Fiona are a lot of fun and not hard to get attached to.  If you're a fan of Telltail's game style with choices and quick time events and borderlands well borderland-y ness I'm sure you'll enjoy it. I can't wait for the upcoming episodes. In the sort of words of Handsome Jack, Welcome Back to Pandora kiddos.

reviewText:
A very nice and funny pattern-following game of the previous Borderlands, all situated in the Telltale's view of making games. The game (as: The walking dead season 1,2 and The wolf among us which i've played before this one) is like a movie, in which you decide what to say and what to do, constantly knowing that everything will have consequences in the current or next episodes.
Unlike The walking dead though, this game has a lot of action situations, where you have to fight back bandits and psychos, with a lot of bad*ss moves of counter attacks. It sure does keep high the interest in the next episodes.

If you liked playing Borderlands 1, 2 and the pre-sequel for its stupidity and bad*sstitude to approach things, then you're definetly going to love this one.

reviewText:
Having now played the whole season, I can easily say that Tales from the Borderlands is the best series in Telltale's repertoire thus far. At its core, it's just another Telltale game akin to The Walking Dead, The Wolf Among Us, and Game of Thrones, so there's nothing too special in terms of gameplay - you know what you're in for if you've played any of those other games. What sets it on the top of the Telltale ladder is the narrative, and that should be saying a lot when you consider Telltale's track record.

Taking place on Pandora, the already-established setting of the Borderlands games, TftB plays around with what it's been given and makes the world its own. I was never a huge fan of the Borderlands games when they first came out, but I found myself enjoying TftB just the same. Where the original series was too try-hard its attempt at edgy and wacky humor, TftB is just naturally funny and brutal, with a surprising amount of those tug-at-your-heart-strings moments we've come to expect from Telltale. Oh, and speaking of which: yes, your choices really do matter here. Well, more than in the other Telltale games, anyway. You'll often be questioning yourself whether or not you made the right decision even in some of the more pedestrian choices, not to mention the life and death scenarios you come across.

In terms of playtime, each episode lasts about 2 hours, with the final fifth episode going well past that, which would clock in the season at an upward of 10 hours for a single run, with plenty of incentive to go back and replay it to see the different outcomes and interactions, since you certainly won't be able to see everything the game has to offer in that single playthrough.

To sum up, Tales from the Borderlands is a must-play for anyone who's a fan of narrative-driven adventure games of the Telltale variety, and offers the most engaging story and gameplay of the bunch thus far.

reviewText: Telltale Games bring their interactive player controlled storylines to the Borderlands franchise. It introduces two protagonists you take control of as you adventure on the world of Pandora. Rhys and up and coming (he wishes) Hyperion guy and Fiona a resident of Pandora. Their lives are about to clash together in typical insane Borderlands fashion. The story has likeable characters an enthralling story and it really breathes an extra layer of life back into the Borderlands universe. It has several laugh out loud moments and brings a real human depth to the characters. Any Borderlands fan should purchase this and those curious about the series and want a narrative experience instead of a first person one, try this.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
This Game is one of the most amazing Tell Tale Games I played by far. Not only that you can play for the first time ever as 2 different characters at once, you also get exclusive borderlands heads to your other borderlands games. The Graphics fit perfectly to the Borderlands Games as they are basically the same. The Episodes were pretty well made and really emotinal, there was everything in it from crying to laughing.

One of the most important things to say about the Tell Tale Games is that it is always like watching a movie but controlling the actions and making the decisions of the characters and feel their consequenzes.

It is always very difficult to make a review about these sort of games because everybody is experiencing something different due to the multiple choices you can make. But at the end of the Game, those were your choices and you will be happy with it.

It is a wonderful story with alot of nostalgia points, which will remind you on other moments you had in the borderlands games.

Even if this is not your usual kind of game I would recommend this to any fan of the borderlands series and of course to any Tell Tale Games Fan.

Also this game is an easy 100% for your perfect games collection. Another thing worth pointing out is that with this game you will get exclusive skins & heads in Borderlands 2 & The Pre-Sequel.

I think no Borderlands Fan should miss out on this and just give it a chance.

reviewText:
Press X To Action
Press A To Laugh
Press B To Feel
Press Y To ...

This is pretty typical Telltale game. You make choices and there are occassionally quick time events. It's not a game where your choices matter so much that there will be +5 different endings. The story goes on from start to finish exactly the same way, but there will be changes in dialogue and in character's actions or reactions based on the choices you make. It is more an interactive movie than video game.

I loved The Walking Dead and Wolf Among Us. But honestly I think this is the best work Telltale has done so far. Tales from the Borderlands is a rollercoaster of emotions. It will make you laugh, it will make you shed a tear, there are adorable moments that will make say Awwww"
date: there are characters you love to hate and then there are moments that make you feel totally awesome... and of course it is incredibly exciting experience. The artwork is beautiful
recommended: but what makes Tales from the Borderlands truly memorable are the fantastic characters with great cast of voice actors.\n\nThe important thing about Tales from the Borderlands is that there is actually no need to play Borderlands
hoursPlayed: Borderlands 2 & The Pre-Sequel to fully enjoy this. There are some references here and there from those games
voteText: you will learn about major events that happened in those games and you will meet some characters that are known from those games. Tales from the Borderlands is more about story where typically Borderlands games are about repeative shooting and looting. I learned more about the world of Pandora in Tales from the Borderlands than in any other Borderlands games.\n\nThe worst time I had with Tales from the Borderlands was 2-3 months of wait for next episode. Now that all the episodes are released

Press Y To ...

This is pretty typical Telltale game. You make choices and there are occassionally quick time events. It's not a game where your choices matter so much that there will be +5 different endings. The story goes on from start to finish exactly the same way, but there will be changes in dialogue and in character's actions or reactions based on the choices you make. It is more an interactive movie than video game.

I loved The Walking Dead and Wolf Among Us. But honestly I think this is the best work Telltale has done so far. Tales from the Borderlands is a rollercoaster of emotions. It will make you laugh, it will make you shed a tear, there are adorable moments that will make say Awwww"
date: there are characters you love to hate and then there are moments that make you feel totally awesome... and of course it is incredibly exciting experience. The artwork is beautiful
recommended: but what makes Tales from the Borderlands truly memorable are the fantastic characters with great cast of voice actors.\n\nThe important thing about Tales from the Borderlands is that there is actually no need to play Borderlands

voteText: you will learn about major events that happened in those games and you will meet some characters that are known from those games. Tales from the Borderlands is more about story where typically Borderlands games are about repeative shooting and looting. I learned more about the world of Pandora in Tales from the Borderlands than in any other Borderlands games.\n\nThe worst time I had with Tales from the Borderlands was 2-3 months of wait for next episode. reviewText:
I liked Borderlands and I liked TWD. So this was kind of an obvious choice for me, I was sceptical at first though, couldn't imagine what kind of a story could be told on Pandora TellTale style. As it turned out, I really loved it. You take control of two main characters, A gal named Fiona and a guy called Rhys. Both come from completely different worlds and carry some heavy baggage with them. You'll get to make dialog and story choices for the both of them while considering their unique points of view, which is pretty cool and I enjoyed the hell out of it. I don't wanna spoil the story and there isn't really a way to explain it in a short way, let's just say it's about vault hunting (duuh), there's mind blowing plot twists and robots and you get very close to banging! Identical gameplay to other TT games - quicktime events and dialog timers. Rarely puzzles.

What I liked:
- The humor! I laughed at every other scene, it clicked very well with both my mature and immature senses of humor. And no, I didn't mind the memes, I think they fit the borderlands kind of a world pretty fine. Maybe I'm too old to find them cool and I don't give a damn.
- The characters. They're interesting and likable, I enjoyed watching their stories as much as simply watching them ;) You will meet new people and some old friends.
- The music, not only licenced songs, also the ambience music really brought my goose bumps up. Opening intros were something I looked forward to much like with the original Borderlands games.
- The story is pretty amazing and nicely paced. Not once I found myself bored of nothing happening or confused from too much action.
- The illusion of choice, still works pretty well in my opinion. I understand why the choices cannot have real impact because that would mean creating 20+ games for the price of one. There are exceptions though, see in the did not like section.

What I did not like:
- Save system, sometimes I made a rash dialog decision or forgot to collect items and wanted to reload, not without replaying the last 10 minutes though.
- Some dialog responses made no sense, especially characters' reactions to my being silent. As I sometimes honor the old saying talking is silver
hoursPlayed: especially with the fallen antagonist. To my surprise
voteText: nobody really minds and Rhys/Fiona kind of continue their animations and face expressions just with closed mouths. Maybe it's just me but I'd be super weirded out if somebody kept quiet in a 1on1 conversation with me.\n- The forced romance. Don't get me wrong
helpfulPercent: I liked Sasha. But since the first moment I only had eyes for Fiona and I felt like a jackass telling Sasha to "screw off" all the time as it wouldn't stop shoving convenient situations up my throat only with her.\n- Bleeping and replacing the F-bomb. I know this is nitpicking
votesHelpful: but COME ON! Is one word really that much of a deal?\n\nThis game obviously isn't for everybody. It's mostly an interactive movie and I think it's worth it if you're into that at least a little. Sorry I can't give the highest score since I did find some flaws
votesTotal: but that did not stop me from replaying it many times and now recommending it to you with the count of 9/10"

reviewText:
Before playing this I had never played anything Borderlands related - and I loved it.

In 2013, a friend of mine gifted me The Wolf Among Us. It was then that I started harboring love for TT episodic games. This friend and I share steam libraries, so I had to try Tales From The Borderlands when he bought it - even if it was just because of the good humor reputation it had. It was a wise decision.

Tales From The Borderlands is funny, gripping, beautiful - seriously, those graphics -, memorable, full of different outcomes and has a FANTASTIC soundtrack - like, as I later came to know, anything Borderlands related. That's why I am now eagerly awaiting the next Steam Sale to buy Borderlands 2 - and perhaps the pre sequel as well.

If you're already familiar with Borderlands, you probably already played this. If you're not, don't hesitate: it's a great way to enter with class into the exotic Borderlands universe.

reviewText:
Absolutely recommended.

It's a great and really entertaining game, i'd risk giving it Tenouttaten.
The characters were likeable, the story and humor were really great (save for some misses here and there, though the misses were mostly related to gags running through the entire series, and the games have a history of having certain writers that i have a beef with, for good reasons).
Nevertheless, the final showdown was 10/10 and so was the ending.
I could say that this reedemed the series for me and re-sparked my interest in it.
A spin-off like this is what the series really needed. Characters and story needed at least one chance to be told through a medium where you do more than just shoot bullet-sponges and cross deserts (at least most of the time), that's not to say that the RPGFPS Borderlands are bad, they just needed something to make them whole. I believe that this point n' click did that. It breathes more life into the world of Borderlands.

reviewText:
*Review is only for Episode 1*

As a fan of the original Borderlands, and a huge fan of Borderlands 2 I am very happy with the first installment of this episodic adventure. The story is fun and quirky and has very solid pacing. Telltale did a great job with embodying the Borderlands world, with its violent nature into the genre they so very well known for. The Borderlands humor is there as one would expect it but it is used in moderation and for the better in my opinion.

On the technical side the game runs well except for the very rare occasional audio bug (which might be a personal problem) where the dialogue would overlap a word and then continue as normal. This didn't cause and de-synch issues or lag otherwise.

After playing the Pre-sequel earlier this year, the Borderlands formula has gotten a bit stale for me. This game however gives me great hope of delving into the lore and the lives of the common folk on Pandora and not solving every problem that arises at 600 rounds a minute.

reviewText:
TellTale does it again!Bringing you a story of love, betrayal and treasure hunt!

Tales From the Borderlands might just be my favourate TellTale game so far.
It's pretty much an interactive movie but we mostly play TellTale games for the story and the story is great so the interactive movie thing is working for it.
The game lets you take control of the main protagonists every once in a while. You move using your left stick and use the right stick to look around...Or you can use the WASD buttons on your keyboard and use the mouse to look around. There's not much to do tho. Just walk around in a very small area and click on things and the story goes on. There are no puzzles to solve.
You spend most of the game either during quick time events or making choices.
People have been saying that your choices don't matter in the Game of Thrones - TellTale Game but you can rest assured that in this game your choices will have an impact on the protagonists and the characters around them.
People actually live or die depending on the choices you've made throughout the game. Even the smallest choice matters. I did something very early in the game that i didn't think will matter much
but turned out having a huge impact on some of the characters during the last episode.
The game is certainly worth playing through twice if you want to see the outcomes of different choices.

I've been a fan of the Borderlands franchise since the very first game. I just love Borderlands! The mysterious feeling the first game had...The music, the humour, the mixed drama and the feeling of being alone in a ruthless wasteland you know nothing about. Wildlife and bandits rule the planet. The Vault was something mysterious. Something that noone had ever seen. The vault was just a story. A myth. - The first Borderlands game
set the perfect mood and atmosphere. The setting of the game was the dung!".
This was all ruined in Borderlands 2. I still loved BL2. The gameplay was great and improved. Same can be said about the characters (Handsome Jack is an awesome villain!) and graphics. But the mood was gone
and so was the mystery. Pre-sequel totally slaughtered everything that there was left of the first games feeling. The gameplay is still good but now the mood of the Borderlands adventure is totally gone.

Why am i telling you all this? TellTale actually kind of nails the atmosphere the first Borderlands game had. If you haven't played any of the previous games (or you've only played the first one) then the Vault is still
somekinda mysterious thing that is very hard to get to. I'd like to think that this game is Borderlands 2. The official sequel to the first game.
The game has a lot of humour in it both dark and goofy but it can also be very dramatic and it certainly keeps the tension up. You just can't wait to see what happens next!
Each episode starts with an amazingly done intro and each episode ends with a well done cliffhanger...Except the last Episode of course. The last Episode does wrap it all up
and you don't have to be worried about the ending being a lackluster. It's actually very well done.

The game features scooping out eyeballs

reviewText:
First Episode Video Review - http://youtu.be/5GuDnjHM4yU

As the first episode in the series episode one is all about introductions and setting the tone. Taking place after the events of Borderlands 2 we are introduced to the two main and playable characters of the game. First we meet Rhys a handsome jack wannabe working for hyperion who has been screwed over for his promotion. Rhys goes planet-side to Pandora to find a way to screw his boss over and become the new star company man. Second we meet Fiona a stylish con artist and pandoran orphan. Fiona alongside her sister and mentor are working the con of their lives and events thrust Fiona and Rhys into a shaky alliance.

In terms of game play the game is similar to telltales previous series. In Zero Sum there's no exploration, its all a story driven linear experience.  There's quick time events for all the action sequences which usually require you to do a combination of moving left and right and then aiming on the screen and hitting the right button. The very few areas you have the ability to walk around there are a few objects to either look at and interact with. Telltales format of story driven point and click has at this point become a sub genre of its own and if you've played The walking dead or the wolf among us, you'll be right at home game play wise.

As is now common place in telltales style of storytelling the game is filled with choices for you to make that dictates future events. Your dialogue choices, action choices will not only effect the immediate situation but as players of telltales previous games know, it will effect events in later episodes. As Zero Sum is the first episode you won't see much in terms of the effects of the things you say but there's plenty of choices in the episode that will have an effect on episode 2 and beyond.

Coming into Tales from the borderlands I was curious about was how they would implement and stay true to the core series and its content. After all the Borderlands games are FPS, loot galore games and I was curious to see if any elements of the games would be brought into this series. Interesting while you don't use it much in the first episode your given a small glimmer into an inventory system. Through out the zero sum episode you pick up a few items but nothing much however I certainly hope that in the future episodes that we see interesting things happen with the inventory system and perhaps that depending on what loot you choose to use, that it effects the outcome of situations.

One thing I was disappointment with which I hope appears in the coming episodes was the lack of puzzles. There was ample opportunity for some good puzzles in Zero Sum, especially when Rhys tries to hack something with his optical cybernetics. Not only are puzzles a good part of point and clicks but I feel they could have been implemented in a really good way in the first episode plus it would have added some decent game play to boot.

Graphically the game hits all the right marks, it looks and feels borderlands. All the locations are well designed and have great detail. I did encounter an issue where the subtitle text would from time to time go out of sync with the sound but its minor. One thing I was really impressed with was the UI design and how it fits perfectly with the borderlands theme. It;s got that futuristic tech feel about it that blends perfectly with the rest of the aesthetic which is great as many games tend to have a disjointed look between the two.

The story without giving any spoilers has been fantastic in my opinion. Story is certainly a subjective thing and what some people enjoy and think is good others don't. One of my biggest annoyances with the original borderlands games was the potential for good story but they never really went anywhere with it. Borderlands two's story was a lot better than the first but that was due to the introduction of a really good villain being handsome jack voiced by troy baker.

Tales from the borderlands story at least in the first episode is told retrospectively by Rhys and Fiona as they have been captured by an unknown bandit who is interrogating them. Not only is the story well told but its packed with borderlands humor too which is very entertaining. What the game does thus far is bring a depth to the universe that I feel was missing from the first person shooters. You will see characters from the other games make appearances too and its all very well executed.

Interestingly enough personally I found more enjoyment out of this than I did the walking dead series. Mainly for two reasons, one, the walking dead became very predictable very fast. Going through, you knew that people where going to die frequently and to be fair I'm done with zombies at the moment.  Secondly, while there is established lore in the borderlands universe, telltale could go anywhere in the story. You feel that they have a freedom with the universe that they never had with the walking dead. It leaves you open to being surprised and interested in seeing the story through.

Overall it was a good first episode. It did a good job of introducing the characters and setting the wheels in motion. I was disappointed with the lack of puzzles and not being able to walk around much. However as story driven games go, Telltale are quickly becoming masters at the art form in this particular format.

reviewText: Of all the post-Walking Dead" series Telltale has done
date: "Tales.." probably strays the most from what could be considered a typical adventure game. You can count on one hand the number of times any of the individual episodes gives you direct control over a character. And that's not really a bad thing; it lets you take control over the things that matter most
recommended: which in Tales' case consists of some pretty great dialogue and enjoyable character choices.\n\nEarlier Telltale games were known - and sometimes criticized - for their branching paths. It's hard to know for sure
hoursPlayed: but "Tales" doesn't feel like its plot would really deviate too much from the choices you make. Which is totally fine by me - it's refreshing that every episode doesn't end up culminating in some "PICK WHO LIVES OR DIES" moral choice that inevitably makes you feel like a horrible monster regardless of your decision.\n\nI guess what I'm getting at is that "Tales" is a genuinely entertaining
voteText: funny and creative series
helpfulPercent: probably one of the best Telltale has done. You don't need to be a Borderlands fan to enjoy it
votesHelpful: though it'll provide some helpful context to some of the series' characters which end up making cameo appearances. Each episode has at least one memorable setpiece moment (Episode 4's "fingerguns" is officially one of my favourite things ever)
votesTotal: and for once the final episode doesn't disappoint. Worth a look."

reviewText: This is my third Tell Tale story driven game, with the walking dead,  the wolf among us, and now Tales from the Borderlands being my third. This is what every form of entertainment should strive to be. This was not only funny, but had depth to the characters that could make you genuinly laugh, and genuinly sympathize with them. It had humor, a dash of romance, plenty of action and lots of drama. This is the most well balanced Tell Tale game in terms of balancing genres, while The Walking Dead was a serious, character driven game, and The Wolf Among us being a gritty, mystery game. If you like Borderlands or any of the Tell Tale games, or just good stories in general;  pick this up!

reviewText:
From start to finish this game is fantastic. The problems are few and minor (mostly graphical issues and sometimes lip synching errors) enough to basically be non-existent. The story is as good as one would hope for from Tell Tale Games using Borderlands lore and writing styles, and the characters are believable, comedic, serious, and most importantly, loveable. Even the lowliest, most pointless throwaway extra is given value for the few moments of screen time they have before likely being gored to death by a rampaging skag.

Also, if you don't want to bro-fist Loader Bot by the end, you are missing something vital to being a not terrible person. Like a spleen.

So do two things. 1) Buy this game. 2) Play the hell out of it, you spleenless, finger gun wielding, skag sucker.

reviewText:
Final Review

This is a must have game, either you are a big fan of BL or just found out about this game and don't know anything about the series, either way you'll love the game from the first chapter to the last.


So what are you waiting for? Get yourself into a story full of nonesense, psychos, insanity, and intense moments as you accidentally find your way to a treasure long gone, many things will happen during that journey, but the question you should ask at the end is...


...Was it worth it?

10/10

------------------------------------------------ Before the last episode

So far this game has been a great experience, thankfully i played The Walking Dead series before this one, so i know Telltale has a good record behind their games, the Borderlands universe sure needed a game like this, it might not be for everyone tho. If you like only the action and shooting of the main series then you might want to think it twice, but if you really love the BL universe and you'd love to see more of it, this is the perfect game for you, no doubt.

Besides, it's a great way to pass the time while we wait for the next game, so, pack your gear and get ready because we'll be going back to our beloved Pandora!

Peace kiddos!

As a Telltale fan-girl I postponed playing Tales from the Borderlands thinking I would need to get familiar with the Borderlands IP before diving into this game. (This is not the case)
I picked it up at a Publisher sale and I have to say I received more than I could have ever imagined. The story got me hooked instantly. The comedic aspect of the game was on point with what stupid silly jokes I usually make so I spent over 10 hours laughing at the screen.

After having success with one style/genre/idea people sometimes overuse it trying to recreate the same virality with sequent games. Best Part of Telltale´s Game Series Yet!

reviewText:
This game is great for everyone, whether you're a veteran of previous Borderlands games, someone looking to learn about the great world of Pandora, or a filthy casual who wants a game to play.

As you all know, TellTale has made an engine they very much love, and that is the interactive story games. Tales from the Borderlands feels a bit like The Wolf Among Us, where you can actually enjoy playing the game, and your choices really do matter, rather than TWD2, where until the end, all roads lead to the same destination.

Personally I have never been able to get through Borderlands 2, I just lose interest after five minutes of killing large creatures with insane guns, however, this game makes me excited to retry the previous Borderlands games, and maybe even buy the newer one.

Each episode is roughly two-three hours long, this game has a total of 6 episodes to be released. Value wise you're getting 12-18hrs worth of gameplay for $20-30, depending on where you buy it from. If you like to think of these games more as interactive stories, then imagine paying around $20 for a 12-18hr long movie. It's worth every penny.

My only gripe with this game is how slowly the episodes are being released, they're more focused on the TellTale Game of Thrones game, rather than this one. As three episodes have been released in the GoT series, whilst only two were released in the same amount of time in the Borderlands game.

Overall this game gets a 9/10 from me, and is definitely on the same level as The Wolf Among Us, story wise. Comparing the gameplay between those two games, they have definitely innovated since last year, and created more interactive elements to their game.

Tales from the Borderlands feels a bit like The Wolf Among Us, where you can actually enjoy playing the game, and your choices really do matter, rather than TWD2, where until the end, all roads lead to the same destination.

Personally I have never been able to get through Borderlands 2, I just lose interest after five minutes of killing large creatures with insane guns, however, this game makes me excited to retry the previous Borderlands games, and maybe even buy the newer one.

Each episode is roughly two-three hours long, this game has a total of 6 episodes to be released. Value wise you're getting 12-18hrs worth of gameplay for $20-30, depending on where you buy it from. If you like to think of these games more as interactive stories, then imagine paying around $20 for a 12-18hr long movie. It's worth every penny.

My only gripe with this game is how slowly the episodes are being released, they're more focused on the TellTale Game of Thrones game, rather than this one. As three episodes have been released in the GoT series, whilst only two were released in the same amount of time in the Borderlands game.

Overall this game gets a 9/10 from me, and is definitely on the same level as The Wolf Among Us, story wise. Comparing the gameplay between those two games, they have definitely innovated since last year, and created more interactive elements to their game.

reviewText:
Best Part of Telltale´s Game Series Yet!
I enjoyed them all, but with 'Tales from the Borderlands' they really created a cinematic masterpiece.
You got to love the kind of presentation they work with here. Absolutely fitting to the charisma of the Borderlands and Handsome Jack.
Their cinematography in this part, how they work music, humor, comments. It is all presented in a movie-quality-kind of professionalism, that totally is most enjoyable!

I cant say much about how much the decisions weigh in this part. It was almost very frustrating how less the decisions affected the story in Telltale Series like The Walking Dead, where I think you could not change much and the different ending where mostly decided in the last two minutes.

Still, playing them the first time was great. And especially in this Series, considering the great expression and the feeling of everything happening around you it is a great experience to play it!

reviewText:
This game is fantastic! Tales from the Borderlands has cemented itself as my favorite Telltale game.

I've played through all of the Borderlands games and Telltale has captured the atmosphere of the franchise perfectly. The story is exciting; complete with witty dialogue, plenty of action, and loads of humor.  The pacing is excellent, your choices/dialogue have impact on the story (rare for Telltale), and the characters have surprising depth.

It's absolutely brilliant narrative that will keep you engaged and chuckling throughout. If you're a fan of Borderlands, I highly recommend this. If you've never played Borderlands it might be difficult for you to understand the background, but I would still recommend Tales from the Borderlands over any other Telltale title.

reviewText: Of all the post-Walking Dead" series Telltale has done
date: "Tales.." probably strays the most from what could be considered a typical adventure game. You can count on one hand the number of times any of the individual episodes gives you direct control over a character. And that's not really a bad thing; it lets you take control over the things that matter most
recommended: which in Tales' case consists of some pretty great dialogue and enjoyable character choices.\n\nEarlier Telltale games were known - and sometimes criticized - for their branching paths. It's hard to know for sure
hoursPlayed: but "Tales" doesn't feel like its plot would really deviate too much from the choices you make. Which is totally fine by me - it's refreshing that every episode doesn't end up culminating in some "PICK WHO LIVES OR DIES" moral choice that inevitably makes you feel like a horrible monster regardless of your decision.\n\nI guess what I'm getting at is that "Tales" is a genuinely entertaining
voteText: funny and creative series
helpfulPercent: probably one of the best Telltale has done. You don't need to be a Borderlands fan to enjoy it
votesHelpful: though it'll provide some helpful context to some of the series' characters which end up making cameo appearances. Each episode has at least one memorable setpiece moment (Episode 4's "fingerguns" is officially one of my favourite things ever)
votesTotal: and for once the final episode doesn't disappoint. Worth a look."

reviewText:
No spoilers in this review.

SummaryMy previous experience with Telltale games includes Walking Dead Seasons 1 & 2, The Wolf Among us, and Game of Thrones. While all these games are similar, I believe Tales from the Borderlands is the best one. It's obvious that Telltale acquired experience from the previous games and they are building on what they've learned. In my opinion, having played Borderlands 2 is a requisite to get the best experience from this game.

Selling pointsBorderlands spirit
The game captures perfectly the spirit, humor, and aesthetics of the Borderlands series, something that it sure to please fans of the franchise.

Story
To my surprise, the events unfolded in this game are not confined to a tiny part of Borderlands universe, and will impact the future of the franchise.

Gameplay
Gameplay wise, there is an improvement over the previous Telltale's games. You alternate between two different characters and the gameplay segments have more variety. It always boils down to point-and-click or button mashing in the end, but there is another layer to better engage the player.

Choices
There are some choices that have important ramifications and/or lead to different gameplay sequences, something that I have found other Telltale's franchises to be missing. Of course, most choices only have a superficial impact of the story, leading to minor variations during conversation ,or the events play the same but with a different supporting character, but I've remained engaged all the way nevertheless.

Voice-overs
Voice acting is top notch.

Underwhelming aspectsNarrative disconnect
When not controlled by the player, characters often take stupid decisions that always come around to bite them back later on, in order for the story to progress as intended. This is something that is common in all Telltale games, but it's worth mentioning anyway because it creates a slight disconnect between the player and its characters, as they are making decisions he would if he was in control.

Animations
Similar to other Telltale games, the animations are often a little stiff or they have weird cuts. At this point, it is probably a limitation of the game engine, but I believe it could use an upgrade.

Additional informationCompletion time (one playthough of all five episodes): 12h
No crashes and the framerate stayed at a solid 60 fps.

reviewText:
Totally what I expect from a Telltale story game.

It tells an interesting story with funny, well-painted characters (in more ways than one) and it really catches the unique pandoran atmosphere and humor. Most of the time I was laughing out loud because of the many hilarious details.

Admittedly you have to be a fan of the Borderlands franchise and of story based games. This not an adventure, not a shooter game, it is an interactive story. Nothing more, nothing less. If you expect exactly that, you won't be disappointed. At all!

I enjoyed the first episode and can't wait for the next. Everyone who enjoyed the TTG The Walking Dead and is a Borderlands fan will love this game. Everyone expecting an action packed shooter game or an intense adventure at least: Move along, this is not for you!

reviewText:
This is an amazing game. This of course still follows the usual TellTale gameplay. This means you better like QTEs and the movie-game style that they use. This obviously doesn't appeal to everyone, but that's how it is made.

The story follows something unique to the Borderlands universe, so it might be best to have a general knowledge of the Borderlands universe-though I feel like only people who have played the Borderlands are going to play this. If you don't play Borderlands you can still enjoy the game, but it might (the story) be confusing a bit in some parts.

The way they inplement rarity and the loot system are really good. I wasn't sure at first how they were going to implement these things but they have done a really good job. There are little loot crates or hidden things which contain money, and then you pick up. There are also some chances where you can buy items (pr pick up items) of different rarity. I hope they will use this system a lot. (You could give the opportunity for someone who has saved a lot of money the chance to get something for only someone who has saved all their money; or someone who bought rare loot could have the chance to sell or use it, and only they would really have the opportunity to.)

As of episode one I am already really enjoying the story as of now. I've laughed a couple times or had a big smile because of how awesome some of the moments were. The characters are very memorable (IMO), and are well done. My only issue currently is that TellTale is updating as much as they said (4-8 weeks) and they have already given Game of Thrones an episode 2, even though TFTB came before it, which kind-of shows where they are putting their time. Other than that it is a great game so far, and if you like any other TellTale game and Borderlands than without a doubt you will love this game...

reviewText:
If the rest of the episodes are like the first two, then this is definetely my favourite Telltale series

If you want to buy the game, then do it. And also, this is not a shoot & loot type like the normal Borderlands games, so if you're thinking this is like the normal Borderlands games, it is not. It is a story-driven choice based game with a few gameplay. But the story is pretttttty good & the writing is neat. So yeah, buy it.

reviewText:
Genre - Interactive Story (Comedy Sci-fi)
Disclaimer I have only played through the first episode.
I have played Three other Telltale games Both the Walking Deads and The Beast Among Us. This would be in 4th place behind them but hold on it is still worth getting.
I really enjoy the Borderlands games and enjoy the comedy universe. This interactive story manages to incorporate some of the frantic action and chracters you know and love alongside new faces. It all comes together nicely and you feel like you are in the universe. The comedy is here stronger than ever, and the voices work well (not sure about Vasquez though, maybe because the voice is a little too familiar). You follow two characters and see how their stories intersect. I really enjoyed the first episode and will play the others as they are released. So not the best Telltale game but still a great game (if you class interactive stories as games that is).

reviewText:
I never thought I would enjoy this game as much as I did (used to the more 'rooty tooty point and shooty' bl1 and bl2) but now I'm waiting with bated breat for Episode 3, while re-playing the first two until my fingers cramp.

The story, simply put, is amazing. Extremely funny, but peppered with just enough tear-jerking moments to get you embarassingly attached to the characters. Tbh, there weren't any characters I disliked, not even the main antagonists. Vasquez and August aren't 'true' villains and are basically an alternate universe you (both have the same background as Rhys and Fiona, they were just a little more ambitious). And don't get me started on Handsome Jack and Handsome Jack theories.

Got addicted to the tftbl soundtrack after that awfully....................good intro. The music was chosen perfectly and Troy Baker's voice is gonna be the death of me.

I'll go back to playing now. Really swell game 11/10

(What? I'm totally not obsessed)

reviewText:
[This review was written shortly after the release of Episode 4, I have not yet had the pleasure of finishing this game yet.]
[Spoiler Free Zone]

Whist Borderlands was a lot of fun to me I found the story to be a little lacking, Telltale definitely spins this all on its head, the story just keeps me enthralled and wondering where we'll end up next and the references to other events in the Borderlands timeline are quite nice nods for long term fans but even if you're not a fan of Borderlands you'll not be missing out.

Easily one of my favourite games from Telltale, I genuinely laughed at some parts, was shocked at some twists and felt like I cared about all the characters involved in this story.

Rhys and Fiona are two vastly different characters but work so well together as your two main protagonists which both have moral dilemmas which you must make for them. Each scene had me wondering what would happen next and each problem and obstacle felt like a struggle.

The music is also top tier, Episode 4 has definitely been the best so far in terms of music, events, scenes and humour.
The villains and adversaries are also highly likable and sometimes you really feel spite towards them which is a great way to motivate a player to feel certain choices are much better fitting to act against certain characters.

So far one of the best games Telltale has made, up there with TWAU, TWD and Sam & Max. I look forward to Episode 5.

DO NOT MISS THIS!!!!

reviewText: Tales From The Borderlands is easily the most connectable and compelling game I have played in memory. I played this game 3 times in 2 weeks because I wanted to know every possible outcome of what happened. The writing is astounding, constantly witty and hilarious. Able to strike a serious tone when necessary. Game plays like other Tell Tale games, which can be good or bad depending on who you are. It's a game that can be casual, but the structure is constantly pushing you to continue playing. The game was easy to play for anyone, allows you to pause at any time, regularly saves so you can exit at any time without losing too much progress. If you're considering playing TFTB and you like point and click game this one will be right up your alley, whether or not you're particularly interested in the Borderlands universe.

reviewText:
As far as interactive narratives are concerned? This is one of Telltale's best - right up there with The Walking Dead (Season one). Telltale have a habit of being rather light-footed with pre-established worlds, where they don't want to tip-toe into the continuity that much- but that's not the case here.

Tales From The Borderlands is a very, -very- solid entry into the Borderlands franchise. It understands the world it's set in and is as appropriately ROFL-worthy as a result. The characters are charming, the writing is snappy, the voice-acting is on-point and, my God, it'll leave you wanting more.

If you like Borderlands and haven't played this? You're doing yourself a disservice.

reviewText:
One of the best games I've not only played all year, but in my entire life. Telltale has really outdone themselves with this take on the Borderlands franchise. While it might not be what the gun-loving, fast-paced Borderlands fans expect, each episode of the series pulls you in with choices that shape your game. I found myself laughing, crying, and sometimes overwhelmed with how all my decisions, from the large to the small, affected my playthrough. The soundtrack in particular is fantastic, and I've already found myself humming or listening to each song on repeat long after I've beaten the episode.

If you're curious about this game and wonder if it's worth the price, I highly recommend it. Get this game, enjoy every moment of it, and enthrall yourself in the story you create. You won't regret it.

Well, unless you buy that secret character in episode 5. There might be some regrets there...

reviewText:
I think this might be my favorite Telltale game yet. Probably because I really like the Borderlands IP.

The game does a good job at giving you the illusion of choice. As long as you don't think about it too much or have overly high expectations, you won't notice the rigid path the story is following. (Well, now you do!) That said, lack of choice isn't much of an issue because the story is quite solid. There was a major rewrite of the plot between episode 1 and 2, so those two episodes don't really flow as well together. Everything else is smooth sailing.

While the engine is starting to show it's age with poor animations and finnicky controls, Tales from the Borderlands does have some pretty awesome gameplay sequences that put it several notches above other Telltale games.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
One of my favourite games ever!
Totally recommended!

If you have played any Telltale game you basically know what to expect. Expect a great storyline with amazing characters and important choices that affect how the story plays out. The only difference here is the 'Borderlands' addition. It basically means take a fun, explosive, over the top coop action adventure game with great humor and write an amazing story for it. Finally, add the well known Telltale gameplay to it and tadaaa you got a gem of a game! Tales From The Borderlands constantly puts a smile on your face and gets you attached to the characters within minutes which results in you being constantly eager to play the next episode in this 5 part series!

In Tales from the Borderlands you control Fiona and Rhys, yes you play two characters which basically allows you to play coop with yourself. Rhys is a Hyperion company man which basically wants to be the boss. Fiona is a con-artists which means she only talks to people if it allows her or her sister to steal money from them. Those two meet on Pandora, a planet known for its terrible inhabitants and thug lifestyles and this results in an amazing adventure together!

My short review of every episode:
Episode 1: Introductions, an amazing episode which immediately got me hooked to the game big time!
Episode 2: Sets up the main storyline, the least fun episode of the 5 which basically consists of a lot of travelling but and main story introductions. It does have a great cliffhanger though!
Episode 3: The main story continues with more fun on Pandora!
Episode 4: Things get really really awesome, best episode introduction ever!
Episode 5: Vault hunting! What else did you expect to do in a Borderlands game? A plottwist and an  amazing  climax battle!

Everybody who likes Borderlands or its humor should totally play this game!
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A fun, wild, laughter-inducing ride! This game intelligently and with classic Borderlands humor expands the story with new characters, new locations, and new mysteries waiting to be unraveled. It also smartly integrates with events from the other games (especially the Pre-Sequel and DLC from BL2), stitching together a few missing pieces while offering up some surprises that will have a major story impact on Borderlands 3 when it finally arrives.

Rating: 10/10
Get it and play it. Great entertainment!

reviewText: I came to Tales from the Borderlands a huge Telltale fan who had never played a Borderlands game. I finished it firmly in the belief that this is Telltale's best game yet. The characters are so lovable, the story kept me on my toes, and the dialogue and writing in general is so funny that I often reflected in mid-laughter how much fun I was having. The writing is so good!\n\nThere's less down time than in other Telltale games, and there's a currency mechanic that's a little under-cooked. On the Borderlands side, my biggest worry going in was that I'd be tripped up by the lore. I never felt lost though, and Telltale seems to have done a good job keeping people like me in the loop without going into lore drop territory.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Brilliant!  I played this with a smile on my face the entire time which was periodically interrupted by laughter or short bouts of 'awe, nooooo' as I found myself immersed in the story.  It's witty, it's entertaining, it's well written, the borderlands references from I, II, and the pre-sequel are spot on!  Play it for the story and getting lost playing the interwoven tale between two protagonists: a witty con-artist and a Hyperion company man.  I absolutely loved the character development.  It's short but well worth the time.  I'm a huge borderlands fan and the humor which was lacking from the pre-sequel was more than made up for in the Tales from the Borderlands.  You'll come across your favorite villians and maybe even a vault hunter or two ;)

reviewText: Welcome to Pandroa! Tales from the Borderlands has to be one of TellTale's best accomplishments yet. The game takes place in the Borderland's universe that we all love, and know. You meet existing characters from the past, and present of the Borderlands franchise for a hilarious and unforgettable journey. The art style is exactly like the Borderland game's, and existing characters keep their personality from the franchise. New characters introduced in this episodic journey are enjoyable, and unforgettable as well. Episoides may take some time to come out, so waiting for all of them to be available is probably the best choice. But if you're itching for some Borderland's humor, don't hesitate to pick it up!

reviewText:
One of telltale's classic story adventures, where you play it like a movie but direct most of a character's dialogue and decisions with a few point and click scenes and quicktime events in between. But like all of the telltale story games there is always a distinctive feature, this one's feature is that you play through the perspective of two main characters instead of one (filled with the borderland hurmor of course).

There are twists, there are laughs, there are times of great bravery and times of great sadness or anger, it might become silly, it might become serious, and most importantly (I think) times of great badassery, from headbutting a psycho to defeating a great villain with one arm and one eye. This game has all the action a story telling game in the borderlands universe needs.

I admit I have made some questionable" choices in the game that I've regretted (not as much as mass effect) but that is the part of the fun in the game
date: creating choices that question your morals
recommended: decision making skills and ability to think laterally is what I love from this game. You might only play it once or twice (and you need some knowledge of borderlands)
hoursPlayed: but it's worth it!\n\nfor a game on decisons and witty humour I give it a 8.5/10"

reviewText:
As far as interactive narratives are concerned? This is one of Telltale's best - right up there with The Walking Dead (Season one). Telltale have a habit of being rather light-footed with pre-established worlds, where they don't want to tip-toe into the continuity that much- but that's not the case here.

Tales From The Borderlands is a very, -very- solid entry into the Borderlands franchise. It understands the world it's set in and is as appropriately ROFL-worthy as a result. The characters are charming, the writing is snappy, the voice-acting is on-point and, my God, it'll leave you wanting more.

If you like Borderlands and haven't played this? You're doing yourself a disservice.

reviewText:
My personal opinion at top, pros/cons in middle and TL;DR At the bottom.

It was a blast. From start to finish, I've never felt that any episode was used for fillers. Every one of them always had something epic and kept the adrenaline running. It was an emotional, stupid, ridiculous, awesome, crazy, weird, painful, destructive, horrifying, bloody, funny and satisfying experience. The story wasn't rushed even with the small number of episodes, the characters that were made for you to love and hate did their job specifically well and the most important part, the choices actually matter! Even the smallest detail can change some outcomes. Everything was detailed and the fact that this game had big changes to the canon story made it even more enjoyable! They made sure to have the spirit of Borderlands in check every moment of the game. If you played Borderlands, buying this game is a must. IF you're a fan though, not having this game would be criminal. I absolutely loved every moment of Tales from the Borderlands and honestly, I can't wait for both Gearboxes' and TellTales' next game to be released.

Great job to both developers for making great games overall. In my opinion, this game would be a 10/10.

Pros

-Great story
-Choices that affect many situations and outcomes
-Keeps the spirit of Borderlands alive
-Every episode adds something to the story
-Good pacing of the story
-Great music

Cons

-Glitchy animation from time to time
-Loading at very important points of the story that ruins the immersion
-Quite a few Ex-Machinas

tl;dr Great game for a Borderlands player and a perfect game for a fan of the Borderlands series.

reviewText:
[This review was written shortly after the release of Episode 4, I have not yet had the pleasure of finishing this game yet.]
[Spoiler Free Zone]

Whist Borderlands was a lot of fun to me I found the story to be a little lacking, Telltale definitely spins this all on its head, the story just keeps me enthralled and wondering where we'll end up next and the references to other events in the Borderlands timeline are quite nice nods for long term fans but even if you're not a fan of Borderlands you'll not be missing out.

Easily one of my favourite games from Telltale, I genuinely laughed at some parts, was shocked at some twists and felt like I cared about all the characters involved in this story.

Rhys and Fiona are two vastly different characters but work so well together as your two main protagonists which both have moral dilemmas which you must make for them. Each scene had me wondering what would happen next and each problem and obstacle felt like a struggle.

The music is also top tier, Episode 4 has definitely been the best so far in terms of music, events, scenes and humour.
The villains and adversaries are also highly likable and sometimes you really feel spite towards them which is a great way to motivate a player to feel certain choices are much better fitting to act against certain characters.

So far one of the best games Telltale has made, up there with TWAU, TWD and Sam & Max. I look forward to Episode 5.

reviewText: Tales from the Borderlands is almost everything I hoped for when I bought it. The first Telltale game I tried was The Walking Dead, but I put it down after the first episode because I found it so dreary and downright stressful (every decision felt like it was going to get someone killed!). Well, that and I hate QTEs. Borderlands, on the other hand, is delightful, light, and hilarious for most of its 5-episode span. And I was happy to suffer through mashing Q" for the story and characters.\n\nTelltales masterfully uses the Borderlands world even though the gameplay couldn't be more different. Several previous characters make appearances
date: to varying degrees of amusement and time. The spotlight mostly shines on the original characters
hoursPlayed: who are very well crafted and voice-acted. The player takes control of two throughout the game and I was impressed that the dialogue always felt 'right' (i.e. no confusing dialogue choices). I may have been lucky but I also really bought into the emotionally charged parts of the game and never felt like the characters were overemoting or that I was apart from the situation (except some excessive antagonism between Fiona and Rhys at one point). It's amazing how much can be conveyed on faces using the stylized animation.\n\nThe music in Tales deserves special mention
voteText: as it seems pitch-perfect for the game. I can't listen to any of the tracks without getting the image of a caravan flying across the desert out of my head- the music and characters are irrevocably linked for me now

reviewText: If you're looking for the pinnacle of Telltale Games, then feast your eyeholes on Tales from the Borderlands. If you're really into the Borderlands series - get this. You'll appreciate the returning character appearances, and likely the story and humour. If you're like me, and were never really into Borderlands - get this. I absolutely adored everything. The characters, the emotions, the everything.\nGameplay wise, it uses the same Telltale model, but with what I feel is much more QTE, which is something I never thought I'd really like, but I actually really liked how it was utilised in this game. The humour is hysterical, and I will not lie, there were times were I sat grinning like a child - which I don't particularly do when I game.\nThis was an incredibly crafted game and my hat goes off to TTG.

reviewText:
I will open this buy saying, stop read, and go buy it.
Telltale and Gearbox trully delivers. If you are a fan of the Borderlands stories, no need for second thought, and just buy it. If you are a newcomer, JUST BUY IT !!!.

This game has its ups and downs, mostly because it slows down really hard just before the climax/final episode. But mostly it's trully entertaining.
With the amazing Story telling style of Telltale and Gearbox combined, you have this Masterpiece that Telltale have ever released compared to their other releases, that is gloomy, sad, and depressing. Yes, This one can get you out of that.

The Characters developments and Decisions that you've made in this game is in no question really, really, really....good. With the ending of the game hinting at another Season of Tales from the Borderlands, or at least (maybe) a Sequel for Borderlands 2 (Oh God, I hope so).
Not to mention, the Action Sequences through out all the episodes is pure gold, Especially the final Episode.

This game made me fell in love again with the Franchise, not for the fun of shootin' and lootin', but for the amazing, colorful, and Interesting Characters that Gearbox has made through out the years. I was kinda skeptical before playing this game, because how telltale is all about serious story telling and how it's going to fit into this franchise, but it Worked ! Rhys and Fiona became one of my favourite Borderlands Character off all-time, vaughn and sasha is inside my list of favourite side characters too. And yes, No one will ever look at a loader bot the same way after they played this game. Especially if you know Star Wars. Yes, Star. Wars. not that it matters.

In the end, I will give this game..
10 out of Gortys Thank yous.
98 out of Vaughn Abs.
5 out of Vasquez Goatee.

and also -1.
Because there is no CL4P-TP.

BUY THE GAME !!!!

reviewText: I'd say that this is TellTale's finest work thus far. While their games seem like one giant QTE for the most part, you always stay on for the story and character development.\n\nTFTB has a lot of comedy but can easily turn to a more serious tone in the blink of an eye. Every character has their own unique charm, but I'd have to say that my personal favourite is Loader Bot; bros for life.

reviewText: If you're looking for the pinnacle of Telltale Games, then feast your eyeholes on Tales from the Borderlands. If you're really into the Borderlands series - get this. You'll appreciate the returning character appearances, and likely the story and humour. If you're like me, and were never really into Borderlands - get this. I absolutely adored everything. The characters, the emotions, the everything.\nGameplay wise, it uses the same Telltale model, but with what I feel is much more QTE, which is something I never thought I'd really like, but I actually really liked how it was utilised in this game. The humour is hysterical, and I will not lie, there were times were I sat grinning like a child - which I don't particularly do when I game.\nThis was an incredibly crafted game and my hat goes off to TTG.

reviewText:
I usually value my time too much to write reviews, but I'll break my rule for the first time and write one for this piece of art.

This has been a great adventure, and I don't think that even the next Star Wars will make me reach the level of emotions I felt in this game.

Telltale Games managed to deliver more than a short story in the Borderlands universe, they gave us the opportunity to experience one of the best story since Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep. I actually laughed in front of my computer for the first time in a while (sad story) and the 5th episode gave me tears of joy at the end. I can only wish and hope that this is not the end & that Telltale will offer us an amazing adventure again.

Universe, soundtrack, humor, characters, fun, tears, everything is in there, just take a few hours of your time to live that.

Thanks Telltale Games, you did an amazing job.

reviewText:
Firstly I just want to say that I have never played a Borderlands title in my life, and admittedly that did put me off buying this for a while, but my god I'm SO GLAD I DID in the end!

I have never laughed so much out loud from a game before in my life. The comedy in this was just genius and so, so witty which is what I love to see as a long loving fan of comedy of all genres. I know it went on about having 'great humour' but I imagined it'd be that dumb, stupid humour lots of people seem to love these days (for some reason) but no, this was great and borderline hysterical. Especially the character Rhys. He was by far my favourite of all these great characters and one I haven't seen in a game before. His silly, sarcastic and cocky personality was something you see in real life but rarely ever in a game. He was refreshing.

What I also didn't expect was an epic tale of friendship and adventure. I literally thought it'd all be sci-fi comedy, but it was far more. So much travelling and picking more team members up along the way on this weird/interesting planet. This game really surprised me in so many areas and I'm so glad I got it!

Telltale really didn't let me down... again! And the finale was incredible. Like Walking Dead it made me cry, but in a completely different way (laughter). EPIC!!!

reviewText: Simply put overall score: 9.5-10/10. Why the 9.5? Idk, just felt like giving it a perfect score is dank.\n\nI love the world of Borderlands, and this game didn't change my opinion one bit. The story was fantastic, the characters were ♥♥♥♥ing great and hilarious and the fact that this shares the same world and timeline as the original games, made the adventure feel authentic. The ending of this game was everything I could've hoped for but...that cliffhanger. All in all, this game is worth replaying to try different dialogue and character choices and I'm just hoping that someday Telltale produces a sequel to this prequel to the sequel.

reviewText:
Just awesome, simply awesome.

First off: Don't expect an Adventure Game here, this is your balls to the walls visual interactive series/movie type of game.
Things that are really important in games like these: Story, Cinematography, Sound.

Telltale Games simply wrote the best Borderlands story in this right here.
I was entertained from start to finish, the openings are ♥♥♥♥ing fantastic, great choice of music.
The humor fits perfectly with me.
It's a gripping Action/Sci-Fi/Comedy Rollercoaster ride which had me gripped almost the entire time.

All in all, the best TTG Title since TWDS1.

reviewText:
Okay, I'll try and keep this short and sweet.
This game was both funny and gripping, and I'd reccomend it to anyone-not just fans of the Borderlands series-as a really fun game. Generally, I'm not a fan of Quick Time Events, but this makes good use of them, and generally the way the choices work and affect the game, it really does feel like you're controlling the story, and you have a vested interest in what happens to the characters. And the story is really the great thing about this - it just works, no two ways about it, and I can't say more than that without spoiling things.
The only downsides I can think of are only four save slots, and the months between episodes. But now of course, all the episodes are out, and I'd really reccomend you get this.
9.5/10

reviewText: I LOVED this game. And I haven't even completed Borderlands 1/2 or Pre Sequel.\nI love the world Gearbox has created for Borderlands on Pandora and the other planets, I love the characters, the writing, everything. Sometimes I'm not in the mood to play a long RPG focused FPS shooter, but I am interested in the story and the characters so this satisfied my craving for Borderlands without actually having to play the FPS. That being said, I definitely want to beat them now to learn more about Pandora and of course Handsome Jack.\nI am a huge Tell Tale fanboy and have them all and this to me is one of their best. It always left me with a smile on my face, and I loved the music they chose as well. In fact I recently beat Life Is Strange as well and I think Tales from the Borderlands has a much more satisfying ending. I give it a 10/10.

reviewText: Bit of a mixed bag. Suffers halfway through from unknown production issues, at the very least including having to write a major character almost completely out due to apparent scheduling issues. Script rewrites leave later episodes of this game with fewer meaningful choices and looking more like an extra fun (but easy) game of Dragons Lair - all nearly unfailable quick time events, no big story moments. However, the first two and last episodes of this game are among the best work Telltale has done to date. At it's best, it's great. It's flaws keep it just shy of the perfect Telltale game.

reviewText: As someone who played the regular Borderlands games, I was wondering how Telltale will make a story driven game out of the franchise. And they far exceeded my expectations. As every other Telltale game your decisions impact the story. But in Tales from Borderlands are two protagonists. Rhys and Fiona. There are also a lot of connections to the already existing Borderlands universe and tons of appearances of known characters. The game provides a lot of action and humor and in my opinion it's one of the best Telltale games up until now.\n\nEDIT: I finished playing all 5 episodes, and this - for me -  is the best game of 2015. I enjoyed it so much and had a great time. I think this one is easily on par with Wolf among us and Walking dead season 1, 10/10

reviewText: If you're looking for the pinnacle of Telltale Games, then feast your eyeholes on Tales from the Borderlands. If you're really into the Borderlands series - get this. You'll appreciate the returning character appearances, and likely the story and humour. If you're like me, and were never really into Borderlands - get this. I absolutely adored everything. The characters, the emotions, the everything.\nGameplay wise, it uses the same Telltale model, but with what I feel is much more QTE, which is something I never thought I'd really like, but I actually really liked how it was utilised in this game. The humour is hysterical, and I will not lie, there were times were I sat grinning like a child - which I don't particularly do when I game.\nThis was an incredibly crafted game and my hat goes off to TTG.

reviewText:
This is by far my favourite Tell Tale game, and that is praise from the highest mountain of which i am laying upon this masterpiece. This is the perfect game for Borderlands fans and just people who like hilarious jokes and really weird things. The things of which are usually kept in the background in Borderlands games because of the time being dedicated to trillions of guns and shooting increasingly huge monsters in the face is here used to expand the universe and make everything about Borderlands better.

For an exampel. I was supposed to strange some bandit. I suck at clicking the right buttons. So i failed. Of course i did. But instead of just retrying it, like each and every other game would when you fail. The bandit cheered me on. Telling me you can do it! i believe in you". It was hilarious and i think it is what shows the soul of this game.

Yes Tell-Tale games are nothing but quick time events and walking around. And answearing a question here and there. But this formula is perfectly put to use in Tales from The Borderlands.

I give this game a 9-10.

reviewText: Tales from the Borderlands is one of the BEST TellTale Games out there. I loved it from the very first moment I played episode 1 and I just couldn't stop. I am highly please with the outcome of ep5, it was worth the wait. This game is very enjoyable, funny, action-packed, chharacters are amazing as well, and the whole of the game takes you into a new world of imagination.\nI can only hope (wish and dream) for a season two. It would be so wonderful to pick where the last ep left off. To continue and follow the stories and journey of Rhys and Fiona. This a very unique game that should continue especially since to take on the roles of both Rhys and Fiona to get their sides of the tales. Plus it would be intresting to see the aftermath of these two.

reviewText: Tales From The Borderlands is easily the most connectable and compelling game I have played in memory. I played this game 3 times in 2 weeks because I wanted to know every possible outcome of what happened. The writing is astounding, constantly witty and hilarious. Able to strike a serious tone when necessary. Game plays like other Tell Tale games, which can be good or bad depending on who you are. It's a game that can be casual, but the structure is constantly pushing you to continue playing. The game was easy to play for anyone, allows you to pause at any time, regularly saves so you can exit at any time without losing too much progress. If you're considering playing TFTB and you like point and click game this one will be right up your alley, whether or not you're particularly interested in the Borderlands universe.
