reviewText:
Tales from the Borderlands is an episodic point-and-click adventure based on Borderlands series. Everything that drives you crazy or make you smile from previous games, or even you’re not Borderlands fan. The adventure spin-off itself contains great elements of scene, humor, violence, and characters.

The game presents strong characters and development even tons of supported characters will play major roles in storyline regardless on your decisions. I do love Fiona and Rhys. They’re funny and conflicted many times, but they have self-interest and purpose on their goals which add different taste on story.

Each dialogue and decision is well-crafted and written which can lead you to an unexpected outcome. Thanks to Telltale games for implementation on great storytelling, twisted plots, and how it fits well in Borderlands’ universe.

The action scenes mostly involve on pressing direction button and short quick-time events. It’s fast and full of chaos. It’s actually pretty fun to watch although some are unnecessary and overused.

However, I feel like the last episode is bit rushed in term of tight sequence. There is not much difference on choosing Vault team. Also, I’m trying to get close to point of interesting and the cutscene just interrupt when player reach certain area. The placement of script sometimes ruins player self-exploration. I also expect Fiona’s cash could play more roles on choices and inventory system could be manually used for purpose.

Tales from The Borderlands becomes one of my great Pandora tour. Not because of its title, but it has mixed feelings of experience and unforgettable taste of what Borderlands should be.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Definitely another masterpiece by Telltale in a different category. It's not as sad and crushing as The Walking Dead, not as mysterious as The Wolf Among Us, but I can tell you that you're going to laugh a lot! I mean it! The story is intese and has its twists despite lack of moral choices. I advise everyone to get some knowledge about the universe so you'll know what is going on. It doesn't need to be that deep though, you'll be explained some things when playing. Honestly I was a bit uncertain if this is the title for me as I'm not big Borderlands fan, but damn love Telltale games and if that's what you're wondering as well, I'm going to tell you to go and get it. It's so worth! And additionaly I want to say they've got great music out there. Now I'm sorry guys but I gotta go finish my finger gunfight...CATCH A RIIIIIIDE... Pew, pew, pew...\n\nHi. <3

reviewText:
One of the best games I've not only played all year, but in my entire life. Telltale has really outdone themselves with this take on the Borderlands franchise. While it might not be what the gun-loving, fast-paced Borderlands fans expect, each episode of the series pulls you in with choices that shape your game. I found myself laughing, crying, and sometimes overwhelmed with how all my decisions, from the large to the small, affected my playthrough. The soundtrack in particular is fantastic, and I've already found myself humming or listening to each song on repeat long after I've beaten the episode.

If you're curious about this game and wonder if it's worth the price, I highly recommend it. Get this game, enjoy every moment of it, and enthrall yourself in the story you create. You won't regret it.

Well, unless you buy that secret character in episode 5. There might be some regrets there...

reviewText:
My personal opinion at top, pros/cons in middle and TL;DR At the bottom.

It was a blast. From start to finish, I've never felt that any episode was used for fillers. Every one of them always had something epic and kept the adrenaline running. It was an emotional, stupid, ridiculous, awesome, crazy, weird, painful, destructive, horrifying, bloody, funny and satisfying experience. The story wasn't rushed even with the small number of episodes, the characters that were made for you to love and hate did their job specifically well and the most important part, the choices actually matter! Even the smallest detail can change some outcomes. Everything was detailed and the fact that this game had big changes to the canon story made it even more enjoyable! They made sure to have the spirit of Borderlands in check every moment of the game. If you played Borderlands, buying this game is a must. IF you're a fan though, not having this game would be criminal. I absolutely loved every moment of Tales from the Borderlands and honestly, I can't wait for both Gearboxes' and TellTales' next game to be released.

Great job to both developers for making great games overall. In my opinion, this game would be a 10/10.

Pros

-Great story
-Choices that affect many situations and outcomes
-Keeps the spirit of Borderlands alive
-Every episode adds something to the story
-Good pacing of the story
-Great music

Cons

-Glitchy animation from time to time
-Loading at very important points of the story that ruins the immersion
-Quite a few Ex-Machinas

tl;dr Great game for a Borderlands player and a perfect game for a fan of the Borderlands series.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
One of telltale's classic story adventures, where you play it like a movie but direct most of a character's dialogue and decisions with a few point and click scenes and quicktime events in between. But like all of the telltale story games there is always a distinctive feature, this one's feature is that you play through the perspective of two main characters instead of one (filled with the borderland hurmor of course).

There are twists, there are laughs, there are times of great bravery and times of great sadness or anger, it might become silly, it might become serious, and most importantly (I think) times of great badassery, from headbutting a psycho to defeating a great villain with one arm and one eye. This game has all the action a story telling game in the borderlands universe needs.

I admit I have made some questionable" choices in the game that I've regretted (not as much as mass effect) but that is the part of the fun in the game
date: creating choices that question your morals
recommended: decision making skills and ability to think laterally is what I love from this game. You might only play it once or twice (and you need some knowledge of borderlands)
hoursPlayed: but it's worth it!\n\nfor a game on decisons and witty humour I give it a 8.5/10"

reviewText:
I think this might be my favorite Telltale game yet. Probably because I really like the Borderlands IP.

The game does a good job at giving you the illusion of choice. As long as you don't think about it too much or have overly high expectations, you won't notice the rigid path the story is following. (Well, now you do!) That said, lack of choice isn't much of an issue because the story is quite solid. There was a major rewrite of the plot between episode 1 and 2, so those two episodes don't really flow as well together. Everything else is smooth sailing.

While the engine is starting to show it's age with poor animations and finnicky controls, Tales from the Borderlands does have some pretty awesome gameplay sequences that put it several notches above other Telltale games.

reviewText:
Tales from the Borderlands may very well be Telltale's finest work yet. Exceeding the production value of both The Walking Dead and and game of Thrones.
ToB is very much a return to form for Telltale, being their first satire/comedy game since the last release of Sam and Max.
Tales provides an intresting look into the lore of the Borderlands universe, and every episodes managed to grab my attention.

I very much recommend picking up ToB on a sale, if you have any intrest in Telltale Games, or the Borderlands universe what so ever!

reviewText:
Character interactions and the humorous nature of the Borderlands series itself lends a great hand to make up for what a terrible technical marvel the Telltale Engine is. Despite the glitches and bugs, this game is on par with The Walking Dead Season One and The Wolf Among US in my book.

The music is fantastic (episode 4's slow-walk intro was certainly my favorite), the voice acting was great, and the environments fit perfectly into what has already been established and then went beyond. The plot writing was fairly mediocre at times, but it was easily made up for by Rhys, Sasha, Fiona, Vaughn, Scooter, and Joe Swanson.

Absolutely play this game.

ps And if you haven't played Life is Strange but plan to, I suggest playing this one first.

reviewText:
If you like the Borderlands series, and graphical adventures, you will probably like this game.

Like most of Telltale Games' releases, the gameplay consists almost exclusively of making timed decisions.  There is little or no puzzle solving.

The Good:
Your choices do change the path to the end, and the ending itself.  The changes aren't extreme, but are present.
The humor and plot is similar in style to the Borderlands series.
The ending is satisfying, or at least the one I got was.
The Bad:
One major character from the Borderlands series appears to die.  I expect this to upset a lot of fans.
While the style is similar to the Borderlands series, it is not the same.  It is gorier and more serious in places.

reviewText:
I think this might be my favorite Telltale game yet. Probably because I really like the Borderlands IP.

The game does a good job at giving you the illusion of choice. As long as you don't think about it too much or have overly high expectations, you won't notice the rigid path the story is following. (Well, now you do!) That said, lack of choice isn't much of an issue because the story is quite solid. There was a major rewrite of the plot between episode 1 and 2, so those two episodes don't really flow as well together. Everything else is smooth sailing.

While the engine is starting to show it's age with poor animations and finnicky controls, Tales from the Borderlands does have some pretty awesome gameplay sequences that put it several notches above other Telltale games.

reviewText: I came to Tales from the Borderlands a huge Telltale fan who had never played a Borderlands game. I finished it firmly in the belief that this is Telltale's best game yet. The characters are so lovable, the story kept me on my toes, and the dialogue and writing in general is so funny that I often reflected in mid-laughter how much fun I was having. The writing is so good!\n\nThere's less down time than in other Telltale games, and there's a currency mechanic that's a little under-cooked. On the Borderlands side, my biggest worry going in was that I'd be tripped up by the lore. I never felt lost though, and Telltale seems to have done a good job keeping people like me in the loop without going into lore drop territory.

reviewText:
By the beginning of the series i could already tell how much of an epic Borderlands experience i was in for, even if it still felt familiar territory from both a Borderlands game and a Telltale game the story and the characters begin to develop into there own and despite some amazing comebacks (some amazing *COUGH* Handsome Jack *COUGH* and some...well i will leave others opinions to that) it strongly felt like its own Borderlands experience which gets better every episode. The action is classic Telltale with Borderlands madness and ♥♥♥♥ing hilarious Borderlands humour (I wrote this straight after the finger blaster gun fight in Hyperion...it was a slaughter with 0% casulties)
I wasn't kidding when i said this gets better episode, because you really start to care about the characters, besides Vallory there wasn't a single character i didn't like...seriously Ellie's Gorty's Robot is even cuter than BB-8. And even when the stakes are higher, the tension is bigger and the story gets even more dramatic and has you at the edge of your seat by the time episode 4 comes...lemme tell you if you didn't feel anything during that awesome Rocket into Space scene then i don't know what will - The game still maintains its witty charm and by the end i hope you agree that this is Telltales finest, i plan on playing this through the whole thing straight one weekend when i need to some hilarious fun and an epic adventure with memorable characters and a surprisingly emotional story, not despressing like other games but emotional because it just reminds me why i love these games and why i love Borderlands.

reviewText:
I always thought that TF2 characters will make perfect TV show but it was until I saw Borderlands 2 where I shot my way out just to laugh my ♥♥♥ off the characters, the dialogs, the craziness and the events.

Therefore I was really hyped about Telltale Series which actually turned out even greater than I anticipated. Not only it’s a pure Borderlands fun without the repetitive shooting routine but since those remaining Borderlandisms are now in the spotlight, they’ve achieved new level of vividness. Facial expressions, visuals, storyline, soundtrack and all.

It keeps the same old attributes: psychos, bandits, vault hunters, beautiful weapons but now you’re “simple” Pandoran / Hyperion clerk witnessing all the madness from the side and fights are kinda tricky for you. Quick-Time Events demonstrate that perfectly.

New characters are lovable: eccentric as always, a bit cyber- and steampunky. Trademark humor and everything but some jokes and cameo appearances will require previous BL experience to get the most out of them.

I personally enjoyed it the same way I’m enjoying shows like American Dad & South Park to say the least. It’s no wonder they have Joe Swanson in their voice cast.

After this somewhat nostalgic title you’ll may even relapse to shooting things at Pandora. Hell, this one is so good that maybe this Pre-Sequel ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t worth a try just to play as Claptrap.

Keep ’em coming.

As a Borderlands fan, I didn't expect much from this story based game, until I bough it. Why did I bough it ? I've played Telltales' Walking Dead serie on XBOX. Was it good ? You make the choices, you play as two characters, Rhys and Fiona, you get to see their relationship change between them and their friends. And also,  Handsome Jack is here too. reviewText:
Rhys is an Hyperion employee who, after being let down by the company, is trying to get rich using its funds with the help of his friend Vaughn: Sasha and Fiona are sisters and con artists pulling a similar scheme on Pandora. Events will see these very different people end up as reluctant allies in an effort to get the money they want so much.
What follows is a lengthy adventure that'll have you meeting characters from the series, visiting lots of places and letting you see what happened after the previous Borderland games.

PROS:

-the graphics and art style absolutely capture the Borderlands feel

-great soundtrack, both original tracks and licensed songs are truly good

-excellent voice acting

-both main and supporting characters are well designed, believable and deep: you'll also get to meet quite a few people from the previous games

-superb story keeps a great momentum from start to finish and creates a perfect rollercoaster between extremely funny and very serious, emotional moments

-very strong final chapter and ending sequence

-the choices presented to me felt diverse enough and influenced events/ dialogues even in later chapters

-good length at 10 to 12 hours

NEUTRAL:

-requires you to have played the previous Borderlands games to get the most out of it

CONS:

-a few graphical glitches here and there

-certain textures are quite pixelated and look bad

-a few problems with sound levels in certain situations (low voices during noisy events, two characters speaking at different volumes): a few typos in subtitles

-some animations look wooden

-no way to quickload if you fail and die, you'll need to quit, get back to the main menu and restart from there: it feels awkward

-no support for Steam Cloud

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=539028296

Tales from the Borderlands is truly an excellent game and sits amongst the best from Telltale thanks to the great story and characters: for a point-and-click adventure it surely manages to cram lots of action and frantic scenes into its gameplay, making it not only a worthy homage to Borderlands but also very fun to play. It's also a pretty emotional journey, one where I laughed alot at the signature Borderlands humour before being surprised at how serious and dark things could become in the next scene.

All the characters are truly well written and ooze lots of charm: this makes it easy to get attached to them or, in case of antagonists, having a bone to pick with them. They also show a believable growth as the game goes on and your choices can shape the relationships between them.

Tales from the Borderlands is absolutely recommended both to adventure gamers and Borderlands veterans wanting to get more of their favourite series (albeit from a different genre): it's an outstanding title well worth the purchase.

reviewText:
This game is funny. If you like Borderlands, if you like Telltale Games, what are you waiting for? I'd definitely recommend it. (Based on episode 1: Zer0 Sum)

The game didn't quite capture my attention in the beginning, and I ended up only playing one chapter per time. But after the other characters (including the sidecharacters) were all properly introduced, that's where the game kicked off (for me). It started to become genuinely funny, with the characters' witty banter and the game's dry humor. Also, Zer0 shows up to prove that he is indeed, way cooler than all of us put together.

This game has given me quite a few opportunities to laugh out loud. It's an enjoyable experience which definitely earns its spot in my library when the vast majority of the games I own only end up making me sad.

One thing I did have to overcome in this game though: UNhearing all the familiar voices in this game. I could not help but roll my eyes when I heard that Troy Baker and Laura Bailey got the leading roles for this game (um, Saints Row, Second Son, Persona 4 and Shadow of Mordor anyone?) but I decided to get the game anyway because at least the two of them have great chemistry when working together and are just terrific voice actors. Other familiar voices in the game are Nolan North and Joe from Family Guy. (There's also Chris Hardwick but I've never heard him in a video game before and he's just doing a good job.) Seriously, I needed 2 chapters to get over myself. But I'm cool now. Get it.

reviewText:
Telltale delivers again. Whether you are a fan of the Borderlands series or not, this is a must play. Tales from the Borderlands captures the essence of the Borderlands universe while standing in its own genre.

This colorful adventure doesn't need gritty gameplay to tell a great story. The drama, characters, and stunning visuals do that on their own. The quick witted dialogue is humorous while still maintaining the levity of a Telltale game. Like always, the voice acting is fantastic. Troy Baker and Laura Bailey do a superb job at narrating this story. It features an excellent soundtrack that really sets the tone for each episode.  Enjoyable from beginning to end.

Tales from the Borderlands is easily one of the best games of 2015.

reviewText:
I really wish I could give this a perfect review, but it is currently impossible to do so. Why? As with most Telltale games, Tales from the Borderlands has an amazing adventure story, but then then you also have to deal with the functionality of the game. Overall, I would still recommend the hell out of this game to anyone who wants a great story that takes place in the amazing Borderlands universe, as long as he or she is ready to deal with sub-par game functionality.

The GoodAs is the case with most Telltale adventure games, get ready for a well written, fun, thoughtful, and action-packed story. There is plenty of great scenes packed into the 10 hours (at least) of story between the five chapters. Telltale does a great job of introducing a ton of characters and weaving them into the already robust Borderlands universe without overwhelming the player or feeling out of place. The writing has the perfect blend of drama and comedy seen from the other Borderlands games to complete an overarching story weaved directly into Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel. By the end of the game you feel for the characters and care about their actions.

Aside from some issues I encountered on my MacBook Pro retina, the graphics are pretty much the same as one can expect from other Telltale and Borderlands games. Pretty much everything is faithfully recreated in Telltale's game without looking out of place or introducing anything that wouldn't belong on Pandora (or Helios).

The BadIn my experience, the game broke three times during the first chapter of the first episode alone, forcing me to force quit and lose all of my progress since the chapter opener. Additionally, The game kept resetting to the default 800 x 600 resolution when in windowed mode, and would be 4x the proper resolution (showing only the lower left corner) when in launching in fullscreen. I figured this had to do with the MacBook Pro's retina display, but still, the only way to get out of it, was to switch to windowed mode (via Cmd + F) then force quit and restart.

I also had some issues with achievements only working when online and connected to the internet. And even after reconnecting to the internet, the achievements that were skipped over would not activate like in every other Steam game. I had to go back and replay the missing chapters to get them to unlock. So beware, if you want the achievements, you have to be online the entire time, no exceptions.

The UglyAnd finally, the biggest issue seems to be similar in other Telltale games, considering they still haven't figured out how to properly use a keyboard in the game. Unless you are using a gamepad, your keyboard is only used for quicktime events or free roam walking. Thats right, no keyboard menu access and no keyboard choice access, only your mouse can can be used in the menus and when making a choice. Given that your pointer can start in the far corner of the window (and extremely far away on high resolutions), this means you will have a lot less time to choose your options as you sluggishly move across the screen.

* As a small side note, it took three chapters to figure out W, A, S, D were the same as the arrow keys, which made switching between mouse events and quicktime events much easier. It was not obvious at first, as they are just arrows on the screen, which made it feel like you needed three hands at any given time to switch between all events.

** Additionally, I played this originally on mobile (Android), and a second time on a MacBook Pro retina.

reviewText:
A TellTale classic, 'Tales from the Borderlands' shows hows true story driven games can define a true gaming experience with as little action as possible.

The characters, the story, the dialogue, the atmosphere are all contributing factors into creating a wonderful game. I'm pretty sure Gearbox helped TellTale to do this, but the game manages to capture the true feeling of the Borderlands universe. The story is wonderful, filled with important decisions you must make to shape its course; the characters are rich and show a vast range of emotions, there's no stereotypical villains twirling their moustaches. The most deplorable ones have relatable moments and sometimes you get to question your 'heroes' motives, it really puts thing into perspective.

The dialogue is absolutely Borderlands-ish. The humor, the wit, everything is there and that's how you get the feeling of being in that universe without actually playing any of the games.

If you liked The Walking Dead/Wolf Among Us, and even if you're not a Borderlands fan, this game will certainly encourage to play of the original Borderlands games.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Do you like Borderlands?

Do you like a dang good story?

Do you like finger gun fights, psycho action, loader bots, Hyperion propaganda, skin pizza, and everything else Pandora has to throw at you?

If you answered yes to any of these things, then add this game to your cart right away. Don't even wait for the sales!

But in all seriousness:

I can really only say that this game is a true masterpiece. So many choices, so much dialogue, so much Borderlands awesomeness. I can't say a single bad thing about this game! It had me hooked since the first episode, and is truly engaging the entire way through. You won't get bored.

If you are big into movies, then this game (along with other Telltame games) is absolutely perfect; it's like a movie that never really seems to end. On top of that, you ARE the movie. You call the shots, affect the dialogue, and you will see that your seemingly small decisions truly make big ripples when all is said and done. I am anxious to make time for more playthroughs!

10/10

reviewText: Tales from the Borderlands is a total masterpiece. It is a story driven game with little combat that you may have come to love in the main additions, but if you love the humor and story of borderlands then pick this up.\nI personally love the lore and stories in all games I play; and even in borderlands do I fine the story to be a major selling point to me. reviewText:
I will say this off the bat: This game is more of an interactive movie than it is a game. Although it's geared to both Borderlands and Telltale fans, most Borderlands fans will be disappointed. There's hardly any segments where you can shoot people, and when there is, it's a bit clunky. After all, it is a point and click game. However, Telltale fans may be disappointed, because there's less interaction than say in The Walking Dead or The Wolf Among Us. I'm both a Borderlands and Telltale fan and I enjoyed it immensely.

In case you don't know, this is an episodic based game. From what I can tell, each episode is about 2 - 2 and a half our long, and there are going to be 5 of them. Using math, that means each episode costs $5 (not counting the Steam sales), which means you're practically watching a full-length movie for only $5. Telltale usually takes around 6 weeks to release each episode, but usually there's a huge gap in between the first and second episode, so watch out for that. You might want to wait until all episodes are out and the game is 90% off.

The story of this game is great. As I've hinted at previously, this does feel like a movie, and has the storyline of one. You play as Rhys, a company man who works for Hyperion, the big bad company if you will. You're a weakling, so if you try to be a badass it usually doesn't work, and the results are funny. You also play as Fiona, who's a bandit (and more of a badass than Rhys). However, both of the characters don't like to use guns, so don't expect first person shooter action. What I liked a lot in this is that killing people is more realistic than in the Borderlands games, so even a single bullet is lethal to everyone in your group.

Now, the gameplay: there isn't much of it. Again, it is a point and click game, so most of the gameplay consists of walking around and clicking on things. However, there are a bunch of action segments (DO NOT use an Xbox controller to play this unless you want a really hard time trying to click" things in life-or-death situations. The buttons are colorful

reviewText:
Episode One Review

Coming to this first episode as a fan of both the Borderlands series and the recent Telltale games projects, I admit to being a little skeptical. The strengths of the Borderlands franchise was also more in its loot & shoot gameplay rather than its stories or its characters, which doesn't seem to suit it well for an adventure game. At the same time, while I am a big fan of Telltale's recent Walking Dead and Wolf Among Us episodic endeavors, earlier attempts at properties that were a bit more action oriented and less walking and talking like Jurassic Park and Back to the  Future were less than impressive.

I was pleasantly surprised, then, when I came away from the first episode of this series with a grin on my face and a sense of excitement and anticipation for the remainder.

The game plays like the recent Telltale adventure games mentioned above, like The Walking Dead or Wolf Among Us. Unlike the early telltale adventure games, Tales from the Borderlands plays out less like a traditional adventure game and more like an interactive episode of a borderlands TV show. This may sound like a bad thing to some people, but I would assure them that it isn't. At least in episode one, this isn't a game about picking up inventory items and combining them to solve puzzles using some sort of Elpis Logic. In fact, there really aren't any puzzles at all. Instead, imagine a well animated and entertaining Borderlands miniseries, except you get to make all the major decisions and live with their outcomes, from how you treat a guy you are asking for directions to whether or not you betray an acquaintance. Most of the gameplay involves this kind of dialogue choosing or decision making, almost all of it on a timer. The rest takes place in rather well done quick time events that take place during the action scenes.

A quick note on QTEs: I'm normally not a big fan of these, and playing with a mouse and keyboard I still don't like the whole mash the q button" one. But

reviewText:
While falling in around 2-3 hour playthrough time for episode 1. There is some replay value there if you want to see more scene's making different decisions.

That said, I definitely enjoyed my 3 hours, it was like watching a interactive movie and found myself laughing hysterically more than a few times. Telltale not only captured the essence of borderlands, but it in many ways surpassed it as far as rich believable characters and lots of humour. I actually got quite upset when I realized I had reached the end of episode 1. I really look forward to the remaining episodes, and you only have to buy once to get them all so win.

Highly Recommend.

reviewText: Single player game, 2 hours per episode, 5 episodes total, 1 episode every couple of months or something like that. Why not pirate it? I bought it, no regrets. When you buy this game you buy tickets to a movie series which you can interact with and change yourself. The continuation appears later on and each time you're left hanging wanting for more. It may be 2 hours but you can keep replaying it, changing the characters' choices which affect the story more than you might think. It has humor, action, thrill and great soundtrack. Yeah I could pirate it, get the same experience but to hell with that; these guys are worth supporting and if you're actually rooting for the companies that don't make ♥♥♥♥ games this one is a good start.

reviewText:
A game from Telltale, inspired (actually, made of) by the Borderlands series.

You play as 2 faces, you see the story from 2 faces, you are Rhys, and you are Fiona.
If you're a Borderlands fan, you'll understand all the humor / jokes the game shows. I would not say that it's like Walking Dead, since this game is pure comedic. Story is interesting, characters are interesting and sarcasm everywhere.

I would recommend this game, but not now. First episode was released a long time ago but no one heard about episode 2 yet. Don't buy this game now, wait for episodes 3 - 4 to be released and then get it.

Score for episode 1: 10/10 (for a point-and-click game).

reviewText:
I will say this off the bat: This game is more of an interactive movie than it is a game. Although it's geared to both Borderlands and Telltale fans, most Borderlands fans will be disappointed. There's hardly any segments where you can shoot people, and when there is, it's a bit clunky. After all, it is a point and click game. However, Telltale fans may be disappointed, because there's less interaction than say in The Walking Dead or The Wolf Among Us. I'm both a Borderlands and Telltale fan and I enjoyed it immensely.

In case you don't know, this is an episodic based game. From what I can tell, each episode is about 2 - 2 and a half our long, and there are going to be 5 of them. Using math, that means each episode costs $5 (not counting the Steam sales), which means you're practically watching a full-length movie for only $5. Telltale usually takes around 6 weeks to release each episode, but usually there's a huge gap in between the first and second episode, so watch out for that. You might want to wait until all episodes are out and the game is 90% off.

The story of this game is great. As I've hinted at previously, this does feel like a movie, and has the storyline of one. You play as Rhys, a company man who works for Hyperion, the big bad company if you will. You're a weakling, so if you try to be a badass it usually doesn't work, and the results are funny. You also play as Fiona, who's a bandit (and more of a badass than Rhys). However, both of the characters don't like to use guns, so don't expect first person shooter action. What I liked a lot in this is that killing people is more realistic than in the Borderlands games, so even a single bullet is lethal to everyone in your group.

Now, the gameplay: there isn't much of it. Again, it is a point and click game, so most of the gameplay consists of walking around and clicking on things. However, there are a bunch of action segments (DO NOT use an Xbox controller to play this unless you want a really hard time trying to click" things in life-or-death situations. The buttons are colorful

reviewText:
This is absolutely one of the best games from Telltale.

As with any such game, it mainly comes down to the story and player choices. Here, the story takes place after Borderlands 2 which is great, cause it sets no limits as to where the story can go. And it does go places and drastically changes the world of Pandora by the end. The journey is full of humor and creative mini-game like battles(The last one is a must play, just for the experience alone.) As for player choice effect, while I haven't explored what other options will do, it's rather obvious certain events will occur no matter what(Major plot events), yet it does appear possible to influence npc perception of your characters(With regards to relationships and who helps" at the end).

The graphics suitably match up with the style from the main Borderlands games and work to benefit as it's close enough to Telltale's usual style. I only noticed a couple texture flicker issues throughout my play
date:
mostly with character costumes but it wasn't distracting.

The music works well and is the same as the Borderlands themes albeit with more of a soundtrack feel now. I did run into a glaring glitch regarding audio towards the end; some audio clips of voiceover and music failed to play close to the end resulting in some awkward silences. I would suggest having subtitles on just in case.

Overall
recommended: I give it a 9 out 10. I very much enjoyed it and will probably play through it again sometime."

reviewText: This wasn't really what I was expecting. It's listed as a point-and-click adventure, but this is a long way from the adventures games I typically play. Dialog choices have a time limit, and you can't save or go back to try a different option. If you don't pick something, the game just continues. I was pretty upset at first because essentially this is Dragon's Lair redux - you just hit left when the computer says left, hit right when the computer says right, click once or twice and you finished the game. But once I realized this was supposed to be more like an interactive TV show than a computer game I relaxed and enjoyed the show. It is a great show. The world is a wonderfully weird sci-fi adventure, a bit like Fall Out: New Vegas but funnier. When you choose the right dialog option it's completely hilarious. Exceptional voice acting and beautiful art. Never played Borderlands before, but now I'm curious. If you are prepared for the type of game you're getting into, you will have a blast. Very good.

reviewText: I'll give that game a positive thumb, but it's not the great game I expected it to be. Sure, it's fun, less buggy and true to the Borderlands series. Made me shed few tears here and there. But that's all to it. Like a checklist they included what makes their games great. Unfortunately, it lacks soul. Most of the time I didn't care what choice I would make - there are lots of them but with little to no context. Telltale should stop doing that good/bad type of characters - usually people just pick one type and stick to it. That makes most of the options pointless, cause you're are not going to go breaking bad in the middle of the season and that leave you with only one option to choose. recommended: neutral to A and you could just go on without moving your finger. Making the outcome mostly the same for all of them does not help either. This is really an interesting game for the borderlands series lovers. It got a great story, it's fun almost never borign, with crazy people (in perfect borderlands2 style) all around.

9/10

Great game, worth the wait (on a side note everyone needs to chill out, just go climb something. No point in sitting in front of your computer waitng and complaing).

Telltale totally captures the borderlands atmosphere, and puts you in a game where you view it from a new interesting perspective.

The only major problem I can see is having Patrick Warburton as a voice actor for the Vasquez character (let alone any character). I know that borderlands likes going for a goofy style that doesn't take itself too seriously, but this character constalntly sounds like he's trying to make a baby laugh with 'googoo gaga' talk. aside from that the voice doesn't even sound like it's coming out of the on screen character's mouth, you can almost smell the recording studio whenever Vasquez starts talking. Really ♥♥♥♥s up any immersion that's been built up.

Aside from that this game is extremly enjoyable, satisfying, and has a good replay value. If you don't share my loathing of Patrick Warburton, then you have no reason not to buy this game.

reviewText:
Tales from the Borderlands is easily the best thing to come out of Telltale's offices in a long while, and blows their other series out of the water (a tall feat). It is pure badass, and retains the feel of the regular borderlands perfectly, and has adjusted to the violent world of pandora suprisingly well.

As with all Telltale games, it's point-and-click centered around dialouge more, but it feels far more fast paced in this, and meshes well with mechanics for combat. The graphics aren't anything different than other Telltale games, but match up perfectly to the normal Borderlands games, and so it feels incredibly real.

What really shines in this is not so much the story, which is very good, but the characters. Every one is memorable and will make you invested, and seeing them become closer and stronger is an incredible experience. This is a MUST have for anyone who likes Telltale, even just a bit, or Borderlands (Unless you play it SOLELY to shoot and loot).

I HIGHLY recommend this game. Seriously, just get it now, and if you're a cheap miser than just wait till a sale, it'll take a while to finish anyhow BUT FOR GOD SAKE'S JUST GET IT IT'S THAT GOOD.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
A well-written action comedy that's a perfect addition to the Borderlands universe.

The comedic timing and the chemistry between the large cast of characters
coupled with a well-paced story make for one of the most enjoyable narratives
Telltale Games has ever created.

reviewText: I normally don't write reviews. But I just finished all episodes and feel the urge to do one. It is difficult to describe my feelings right now. This game is just awesome. reviewText: Excellent storytelling and very likeable characters. Troy Baker and Laura Bailey do an outstanding job voicing the two atypical protagonists.\n\nThis captures the atmosphere of Borderlands perfectly, but it does a better job telling its story than Borderlands 1 or 2. reviewText:
This game is great.

If you like Borderlands for the story and setting, then you will love this game.
If you like Borderlands for the gameplay and hate the story of Borderlands, then you may not like this game.
If you hate Borderlands you will most likely not like this game.

+Fun story, likeable characters, makes you feel emotions
-Decisions dont have heaps of impact in terms of major changes in the story
